edu.uw.cs.cse461.net.rpc

Class RPCCall

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.uw.cs.cse461.net.base.NetLoadable
      • edu.uw.cs.cse461.net.base.NetLoadable.NetLoadableService
        • edu.uw.cs.cse461.net.rpc.RPCCall
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    NetLoadableInterface, NetLoadableInterface.NetLoadableServiceInterface

    public class RPCCall
extends NetLoadable.NetLoadableService
    Class implementing the caller side of RPC -- the RPCCall.invoke() method. The invoke() method itself is static, for the convenience of the callers, but this class is a normal, loadable, service.

    This class is responsible for implementing persistent connections. (What you might think of as the actual remote call code is in RCPCallerSocket.java.) Implementing persistence requires keeping a cache that must be cleaned periodically. We do that using a cleaner thread.

    Author:
    zahorjan

    • Method Detail

      • invoke

        public static org.json.JSONObject invoke(String ip,
                         int port,
                         String serviceName,
                         String method,
                         org.json.JSONObject userRequest,
                         int socketTimeout)
                                  throws org.json.JSONException,
                                         IOException
        Invokes method() on serviceName located on remote host ip:port.
        Parameters:
        ip - Remote host's ip address
        port - RPC service port on remote host
        serviceName - Name of service to be invoked
        method - Name of method of the service to invoke
        userRequest - Arguments to call
        socketTimeout - Maximum time to wait for a response, in msec.
        Returns:
        Returns whatever the remote method returns.
        Throws:
        org.json.JSONException
        IOException

      • invoke

        public static org.json.JSONObject invoke(String ip,
                         int port,
                         String serviceName,
                         String method,
                         org.json.JSONObject userRequest)
                                  throws org.json.JSONException,
                                         IOException
        A convenience implementation of invoke() that doesn't require caller to set a timeout. The timeout is set to the net.timeout.socket entry from the config file, or 2 seconds if that doesn't exist.
        Throws:
        org.json.JSONException
        IOException

      • _invoke

        private org.json.JSONObject _invoke(String ip,
                          int port,
                          String serviceName,
                          String method,
                          org.json.JSONObject userRequest,
                          int socketTimeout,
                          boolean tryAgain)
                             throws org.json.JSONException,
                                    IOException
        This private method performs the actual invocation, including the management of persistent connections. Note that because we may issue the call twice, we may (a) cause it to be executed twice at the server(!), and (b) may end up blocking the caller for around twice the timeout specified in the call. (!)
        Parameters:
        ip -
        port -
        serviceName -
        method -
        userRequest -
        socketTimeout - Max time to wait for this call
        tryAgain - Set to true if you want to repeat call if a socket error occurs; e.g., persistent socket is no good when you use it
        Returns:
        Throws:
        org.json.JSONException
        IOException

      • shutdown

        public void shutdown()
        Description copied from class: NetLoadable
        Called by the infrastructure when this loadable should shut down. Subclasses are likely to define more specific shutdown() implementations. For example, if they have started any threads, its important that those threads be terminated - otherwise, the application as a whole may not terminate. Subclass implementations should always invoke this implementation as the first thing they do.
        Specified by:
        shutdown in interface NetLoadableInterface
        Overrides:
        shutdown in class NetLoadable
